text:
2020 JUN 05 (NewsRx) -- By a News Reporter-Staff News Editor at Middle East
Daily \-- Research findings on Life Science Research \- Biology are discussed
in a new report. According to news reporting originating in Riyadh, Saudi
Arabia, by NewsRx journalists, research stated, "Asian citrus psyllid is a
most damaging insect pest of citrus. In this field study, the efficacy of
seven insecticides (emamectin benzoate, bifenthrin, chlorfenapyr, fipronil,
imidacloprid, pyriproxyfen and thiamethoxam) was evaluated against Diaphorina
citri Kuwayama in the citrus orchard of Kinnow mandarin, Citrus reticulata
Blanco."

Financial support for this research came from Deanship of Scientific Research
at King Saud University, Saudi Arabia through College of Food and Agriculture
Sciences Research Center.

The news reporters obtained a quote from the research from King Saud
University, "The insecticides revealed a differential and substantial relative
efficacy against D. citri compared to the untreated plants. The insecticidal
effect attributed as percent reduction in insect population was more prominent
after three days of spray: highest reduction values were recorded with
thiamethoxam (50.89%), imidacloprid (44.27%) and bifenthrin (42.94%) after
first spray, and thiamethoxam (83.36%), imidacloprid (73.20%) and bifenthrin
(72.66%) after second spray. Thus, neonicotinoids (thiamethoxam and
imidacloprid) and pyrethroid (bifenthrin) resulted as highly effective against
D. citri at three days after both sprays. At seven days, imidacloprid (63.53%)
and fipronil (62.47%) presented relatively higher population reduction after
first spray, and thiamethoxam (92.66%) and chlorfenapyr (89.59%) after second
spray. At 12 days, the insecticidal effect on insect population became
significantly at par after each spray except chlorfenapyr that reflected high
population reduction (93.17%) only after second spray."

According to the news reporters, the research concluded: "It is also obvious
from the data that there is need of regular monitoring to suppress the
psyllids population below threshold level by timely application of the second
insecticidal spray."

For more information on this research see: A Field Study Investigating the
Insecticidal Efficacy Against Diaphorina Citri Kuwayama On Kinnow Mandarin,
Citrus Reticulata Blanco Trees. _Saudi Journal of Biological Sciences_ ,
2020;27(5):1237-1241. _Saudi Journal of Biological Sciences_ can be contacted
at: Elsevier, Radarweg 29, 1043 Nx Amsterdam, Netherlands. (Elsevier \-
[www.elsevier.com](http://www.elsevier.com); Saudi Journal of Biological
Sciences \- <http://www.journals.elsevier.com/saudi-journal-of-biological-
sciences/>)

Our news correspondents report that additional information may be obtained by
contacting J. Iqbal, King Saud University, College of Food and Agricultural
Science, Dept. of Plant Protection, Riyadh, Saudi Arabia. Additional authors
for this research include A.A. Owayss, H.S. Raweh, A.S. Alqarni, H.N. Hussain,
M. Latif and M.B. Baig.

The direct object identifier (DOI) for that additional information is:
<https://doi.org/10.1016/j.sjbs.2020.02.006>. This DOI is a link to an online
electronic document that is either free or for purchase, and can be your
direct source for a journal article and its citation.

(Our reports deliver fact-based news of research and discoveries from around
the world.)

title: New Biology Study Results Reported from King Saud University (A Field Study Investigating the Insecticidal Efficacy Against Diaphorina Citri Kuwayama On Kinnow Mandarin, Citrus Reticulata Blanco Trees): Life Science Research - Biology
html:
2020 JUN 05 (NewsRx) -- By a News Reporter-Staff News Editor at Middle East Daily -- Research findings on Life Science Research - Biology are discussed in a new report. According to news reporting originating in Riyadh, Saudi Arabia, by NewsRx journalists, research stated, “Asian citrus psyllid is a most damaging insect pest of citrus. In this field study, the efficacy of seven insecticides (emamectin benzoate, bifenthrin, chlorfenapyr, fipronil, imidacloprid, pyriproxyfen and thiamethoxam) was evaluated against Diaphorina citri Kuwayama in the citrus orchard of Kinnow mandarin, Citrus reticulata Blanco.”

Financial support for this research came from Deanship of Scientific Research at King Saud University, Saudi Arabia through College of Food and Agriculture Sciences Research Center.

The news reporters obtained a quote from the research from King Saud University, “The insecticides revealed a differential and substantial relative efficacy against D. citri compared to the untreated plants. The insecticidal effect attributed as percent reduction in insect population was more prominent after three days of spray: highest reduction values were recorded with thiamethoxam (50.89%), imidacloprid (44.27%) and bifenthrin (42.94%) after first spray, and thiamethoxam (83.36%), imidacloprid (73.20%) and bifenthrin (72.66%) after second spray. Thus, neonicotinoids (thiamethoxam and imidacloprid) and pyrethroid (bifenthrin) resulted as highly effective against D. citri at three days after both sprays. At seven days, imidacloprid (63.53%) and fipronil (62.47%) presented relatively higher population reduction after first spray, and thiamethoxam (92.66%) and chlorfenapyr (89.59%) after second spray. At 12 days, the insecticidal effect on insect population became significantly at par after each spray except chlorfenapyr that reflected high population reduction (93.17%) only after second spray.”

According to the news reporters, the research concluded: “It is also obvious from the data that there is need of regular monitoring to suppress the psyllids population below threshold level by timely application of the second insecticidal spray.”

For more information on this research see: A Field Study Investigating the Insecticidal Efficacy Against Diaphorina Citri Kuwayama On Kinnow Mandarin, Citrus Reticulata Blanco Trees. Saudi Journal of Biological Sciences, 2020;27(5):1237-1241. Saudi Journal of Biological Sciences can be contacted at: Elsevier, Radarweg 29, 1043 Nx Amsterdam, Netherlands. (Elsevier - www.elsevier.com; Saudi Journal of Biological Sciences - http://www.journals.elsevier.com/saudi-journal-of-biological-sciences/)

Our news correspondents report that additional information may be obtained by contacting J. Iqbal, King Saud University, College of Food and Agricultural Science, Dept. of Plant Protection, Riyadh, Saudi Arabia. Additional authors for this research include A.A. Owayss, H.S. Raweh, A.S. Alqarni, H.N. Hussain, M. Latif and M.B. Baig.

The direct object identifier (DOI) for that additional information is: https://doi.org/10.1016/j.sjbs.2020.02.006. This DOI is a link to an online electronic document that is either free or for purchase, and can be your direct source for a journal article and its citation.

(Our reports deliver fact-based news of research and discoveries from around the world.)
